newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian bonds end mixed, curve flatter after ease.
newsitem.headline: Canadian bonds end mixed, curve flatter after ease.

text.p: Canadian bonds closed mixed on Thursday following a rate cut by the Bank of Canada as investors sold off short-term issues to buy longer-term bonds, analysts said.

"The short end was overdone going into the Bank's easing," said one Toronto-based bond dealer. "The market had already discounted a quarter point. It was starting to discount more than that and they just took it back."
Canada's 8.0 percent bond due 2023 rose C$0.25 to C$103.00 to yield 7.731 percent. The U.S. 30-year benchmark fell 2/32 to yield 6.84 percent.
The spread between the bonds narrowed to 89 basis points from 91 basis points at Wednesday's close.
The Bank of Canada cut its key Bank Rate by 25 basis points to 4.25 percent and lowered the target range for its overnight lending rate to 3.75-4.25 percent on Thursday.
The move by the Bank followed a decision by Germany's Bundesbank to cut short-term interest rates. The Bundesbank's move triggered rate cuts in other European countries.
The Bank of Canada issued a statement following the easing which analysts said suggested the Bank will not lower rates further.
In the statement, the Bank said the cumulative interest rate cuts now in place are "substantial" and can be expected to have a positive impact on the economy over the next year or so.
Expectations the Bank will not ease again prompted investors to take profits on shorter-term issues and buy longer-term bonds which have more attractive yields, analysts said.
In new issue news, the Government of Canada said it plans to auction on August 28 a total of C$400 million of 4.25 percent real return bonds maturing on Decmeber 1, 2026.
In other prices, the 7.0 percent of 2006 rose C$0.01 to C$98.20 to yield 7.249 percent. The U.S. 10-year benchmark fell 1/32 to yield 6.62 percent.
The spread between the two bonds narrowed to 63 basis points from 64 basis points at Wednesday's close.
The three-month cash bill traded at 3.99 percent against the U.S. three-month bill at 5.13 percent.
